title: Definite Articles: Bulgarian vs German

cultural_context.bulgarian_perspective: Bulgarian attaches definite articles as suffixes to nouns (-ът, -та, -то), making them invisible to German speakers initially. This reflects Bulgarian's synthetic nature - information is packed into word endings.
cultural_context.german_perspective: German places articles before nouns (der, die, das), which feels more familiar to Bulgarian speakers learning German. However, German articles change based on case, which Bulgarian lacks.

cross_linguistic_explanation.bg_to_de: Als Bulgare kennst du bereits das Konzept der Bestimmtheit durch -ът/-та/-то. Im Deutschen steht der Artikel VOR dem Substantiv: 'човекът' → 'der Mann'. Aber Achtung: Deutsche Artikel ändern sich je nach Fall (Nominativ/Akkusativ/Dativ/Genitiv).
cross_linguistic_explanation.de_to_bg: As a German speaker, you're used to 'der/die/das' before nouns. Bulgarian attaches these AFTER the noun as endings: 'der Mann' → 'мъжът'. Think of it as the article 'melting' into the word itself.

examples.explanation_bg_to_de: Beachte: -ът wird zu 'der', -та wird zu 'das' (nicht 'die', weil 'Buch' neutral ist)
examples.explanation_de_to_bg: Notice: 'der' becomes -ът, 'das' becomes -та (книга is feminine in Bulgarian)

bg_to_de: Using 'die Buch' instead of 'das Buch' - German noun gender differs from Bulgarian
de_to_bg: Forgetting that Bulgarian articles are suffixes: saying 'the човек' instead of 'човекът'

cultural_insight: This difference reflects deeper cultural patterns: Bulgarian's suffix system shows how information can be 'hidden' within words (like how Bulgarian culture values subtlety), while German's prefix system reflects directness and clarity valued in German culture.

title: Verb Aspects: Bulgarian Perfective/Imperfective vs German

cultural_context.bulgarian_perspective: Bulgarian speakers think in terms of completed vs ongoing actions (свършен/несвършен вид). This aspectual thinking is deeply rooted in Slavic worldview - actions are either 'finished business' or 'ongoing process'.
cultural_context.german_perspective: German speakers rely more on tense (Präsens, Präteritum, Perfekt) rather than aspect. German precision culture prefers exact time specification over action completion status.

cross_linguistic_explanation.bg_to_de: Dein bulgarisches 'свършен вид' (perfektiv) entspricht oft dem deutschen Perfekt: 'прочетох' → 'ich habe gelesen'. Aber Vorsicht: Deutsches Präsens kann beide bulgarische Aspekte ausdrücken! 'чета' und 'прочета' können beide 'ich lese' sein.
cross_linguistic_explanation.de_to_bg: Your German tenses don't map directly to Bulgarian aspects. 'Ich lese' could be 'чета' (ongoing) or 'прочета' (will complete). Bulgarian forces you to decide: is this action ongoing or will it be completed?

examples.german: Ich las ein Buch vs Ich habe ein Buch gelesen
examples.explanation_bg_to_de: Beide bulgarische Aspekte können deutsches Präteritum oder Perfekt werden - der Kontext entscheidet
examples.explanation_de_to_bg: German past tenses don't specify completion - you must choose the Bulgarian aspect based on meaning

bg_to_de: Overusing Perfekt when Präsens would be natural: 'Ich habe jeden Tag gelesen' instead of 'Ich lese jeden Tag'
de_to_bg: Using imperfective when perfective is needed: 'четях' instead of 'прочетох' for completed actions

cultural_insight: This reflects different cultural approaches to time and completion: Bulgarian culture emphasizes whether something is 'done' or 'in process' (Orthodox concept of spiritual completion), while German culture emphasizes precise temporal placement (Protestant work ethic's time management).

title: Politeness and Formality: Ви vs Sie

cultural_context.bulgarian_perspective: Bulgarian 'Ви' (formal you) is used more selectively - primarily for elderly, authority figures, or very formal situations. Bulgarian culture values warmth and quick transition to informal 'ти'.
cultural_context.german_perspective: German 'Sie' is used much more broadly and maintained longer in relationships. German culture values professional distance and formal respect even among colleagues.

cross_linguistic_explanation.bg_to_de: Dein bulgarisches 'Ви' entspricht deutschem 'Sie', aber Deutsche benutzen 'Sie' viel länger! Auch Kollegen siezen sich oft jahrelang. Warte auf das Angebot zum 'Du'.
cross_linguistic_explanation.de_to_bg: Your German 'Sie' maps to Bulgarian 'Ви', but Bulgarians switch to 'ти' much faster. Don't be surprised if someone offers 'ти' after just a few meetings - it's friendliness, not disrespect.

examples.bulgarian: Как сте? (formal) → Как си? (informal, often after 1-2 meetings)
examples.german: Wie geht es Ihnen? (formal, might continue for months/years)
examples.explanation_bg_to_de: Deutsche Formalität dauert länger - sei geduldig mit 'Sie'
examples.explanation_de_to_bg: Bulgarian informality comes faster - 'ти' is offered as friendship

bg_to_de: Switching to 'Du' too quickly - wait for the German person to suggest it
de_to_bg: Being offended when offered 'ти' quickly - it's Bulgarian warmth, not presumption

cultural_insight: Reflects cultural values: Bulgarian Orthodox tradition of spiritual equality leads to faster informal address, while German Protestant tradition of social order maintains formal distance longer.

title: Word Order: Bulgarian Flexibility vs German Structure

cultural_context.bulgarian_perspective: Bulgarian allows flexible word order for emphasis and emotion - you can move words around to highlight what's important. This reflects Bulgarian storytelling tradition and emotional expressiveness.
cultural_context.german_perspective: German has stricter word order rules (V2 in main clauses, verb-final in subordinate clauses). This reflects German cultural values of order, predictability, and systematic thinking.

cross_linguistic_explanation.bg_to_de: Deine bulgarische Wortstellungsfreiheit gibt es im Deutschen nicht! Deutsche Sätze folgen festen Regeln: Verb an Position 2 im Hauptsatz, am Ende im Nebensatz. 'Тази книга я четох вчера' muss werden 'Dieses Buch habe ich gestern gelesen' (nicht 'Dieses Buch gestern ich gelesen habe').
cross_linguistic_explanation.de_to_bg: German's strict word order doesn't exist in Bulgarian! You can move words around for emphasis: 'Ich las gestern das Buch' can become 'Книгата я четох вчера' (book-focused) or 'Вчера четох книгата' (time-focused).

examples.bulgarian: Книгата я четох вчера / Вчера четох книгата / Четох вчера книгата (all correct, different emphasis)
examples.german: Das Buch habe ich gestern gelesen (only this order is correct)
examples.explanation_bg_to_de: Deutsche Wortstellung ist fest - lerne die Regeln auswendig
examples.explanation_de_to_bg: Bulgarian word order is free - use it to emphasize different parts

bg_to_de: Putting verbs in wrong positions: 'Ich gestern das Buch gelesen habe' instead of 'Ich habe gestern das Buch gelesen'
de_to_bg: Using only one word order pattern - missing opportunities for emphasis through word order variation

cultural_insight: Word order reflects cultural communication styles: Bulgarian flexibility mirrors the culture's adaptability and emotional expressiveness, while German structure reflects systematic thinking and preference for clear, predictable communication.
